results.title: Charles Mingus: triumph of the underdog
results.brief_description: Nine years in the making, this is the definitive tribute to the complex personality and musical genius that was Charles Mingus. Director McGlynn has unearthed a wonderful array of previously unseen or extremely rare film and television clips of Mingus in performance, and combines these with contributions from his friends, fellow musicians, and family to create a unique insight into the creative process, and a life full of trauma, frustration and joy. Includes musical performances by Duke Ellington, Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Bud Powell and many more.

results.title: Charles Hackett, 392 Reel Three Vitaphone record
results.brief_description:
Reel three of a short film about tenor singer Charles Hackett.

Vitaphone was a sound film system used for feature films and nearly 1,000 short subjects made by Warner Bros. and its sister studio First National from 1926 to 1931. Vitaphone was the last major analog sound-on-disc system and the only one which was widely used and commercially successful.

results.title: Charles Dickens: background for his works
results.brief_description: Scenes photographed in England, showing many of the actual places which Dickens used as settings in his novels and also town and country houses where he wrote some of his best-known novels. Views of historic inns and buildings in London, Rochester, Canterbury, Dover and the marshlands of “Great Expectations”. A page from the MS of “Pickwick Papers”; another from the MS of “Oliver Twist”. The film stresses the relation between Dickens’ stories and his personal experience of places, people and social customs.

results.title: Charles Dicken's expectations: a dream of childhood
results.creator_credit: Paul Kafno, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th century novel”.
Graham Martin explores Pip’s character in terms of the surrender of childish dreams, and draws parallels with Dickens’ own life. The film is set on locations in Kent, at Dickens’ home at Gade Hill, and in London. Presented by Graham Martin, reader in literature. Voice of Charles Dickens read by Gabriel Woolf.

results.title: Charles Darwin
results.brief_description: “Summary: presents the discoveries, method of study, theories and personal philosophy of charles darwin. describes his observations on the galapagos finches which later figured in his conclusions on organic evolution. features professor richard eakin of the university of california in the role of the scientist”

results.title: Charles Chauvel: the action director
results.brief_description: Compilation film containing interviews with Elsa Chauvel, Sir Norman Rydge, Chips Rafferty, Betty Bryant, Marsden Hessall, and others who worked with Charles Chauvel. Long excerpts from his seven sound features, including “40,000 Horsemen” and “Jedda”. Includes B&W sequences.

results.title: Charles Blackman: dreams and shadows
results.creator_credit: Richard Moore, ABC-TV (Australia) and RM Films
results.brief_description: Charles Blackman has been described as the “traditional Aussie battler”. Raised by his mother in a home with no books and little furniture or food, Blackman rose above the insecurity of his life to become one of Australia’s most celebrated artists. A chronological look at Blackman’s life and work and his unique contribution to the development of the Australian identity is provided. Narrated by Kate Fitzpatrick.

results.title: Charlemagne: holy barbarian
results.creator_credit: Victor Vicas, Learning Corporation of America and International Film Associates
results.brief_description: The story of Charlemagne’s campaign against the Saxons. Focuses on one campaign waged by Charlemagne against the Saxons in 782, in order to examine whether brutality in the name of civilisation is justified. Discusses the cultural contribution of Charlemagne, and shows the ruthless means he employed to accomplish his goals.

results.title: Charlemagne and his empire
results.brief_description: Pictures Charlemagne’s conquests , his close ties with the Roman Church, his system of government, and his many contributions to life in the Middle Ages. Shows how Charlemagne hoped to keep civilization and culture alive on the European continent during the early years of the Middle Ages. No other credits available.
